items.title: Minister apologizes for 'poor choice of words' about meeting with B.C. First Nations group
items.summary_auto: Federal Energy Minister Tim Hodgson says he has apologized to Coastal First Nations for what he says were a “poor choice of words” regarding a meeting he offered to have with the group on Friday.

items.title: Manitoba will begin Brady Road landfill search for remains of First Nations women on Monday
items.summary_auto: A search of another Winnipeg landfill for the remains of First Nations women will begin on Monday, CBC News has learned.

items.title: Manitoba sticking to U.S. alcohol ban since it's a 'pain point' for Trump: premier
items.summary_auto: Manitoba Premier Wab Kinew showed no willingness Friday to relax his province's ban on American alcohol products. He argued the prohibition, enacted by several provinces, has been one of Canada's responses to the U.S. trade dispute the Trump administration has noticed.

items.title: These are the airlines most affected by the massive Airbus A320 recall
Crown seeks jail for former Saskatoon Christian school principal guilty of assaulting student
items.summary_auto: The Crown prosecution says Duff Friesen should serve jail time for assaulting a student. His lawyer wants a conditional discharge.

items.title: After 10 years of delay, the controversial Thirty Meter Telescope may finally get built — in Spain
items.summary_auto: Bob's Blog: A long-delayed project to build the largest telescope in the Northern Hemisphere atop Mauna Kea in Hawaii has been given new life, as Spain has offered new funding and a new location on the island of La Palma.

items.title: Liberals say caucus is united despite former environment minister's resignation from cabinet
items.summary_auto: Some Liberal MPs are insisting their caucus remains united despite Steven Guilbeault’s decision to quit cabinet over Prime Minister Mark Carney’s deal with Alberta that could lead to a pipeline to the B.C. coast.

items.title: Student grabbed by sex offender in Winnipeg elementary school bathroom, police say
items.summary_auto: Winnipeg police say a child was grabbed by a stranger in a St. Vital elementary school bathroom Thursday, leading to charges of assault and forcible confinement against a 28-year-old man who is a registered sex offender.

items.title: 'Made-up quote' in Canadian satire site The Beaverton fools Time Magazine
items.summary_auto: In a recent article about the United States' strained relationships with other countries, Time Magazine included a made-up quote from Canadian satire site The Beaverton — seemingly as fact.

items.title: Surging measles cases could augur poorly for other diseases, World Health Organization says
items.summary_auto: Measles deaths dropped 88 per cent over 24 years thanks to global immunization efforts but the number of cases surged in 2024, the World Health Organization says.

items.title: Israeli forces kill at least 13 in southern Syria raid, officials and residents say
items.summary_auto: Israeli forces in southern Syria raided a village and opened fire when they were confronted by residents on Friday, killing at least 13, Syrian officials said, as Israel fights on a number of fronts while the shaky ceasefire in Gaza moves forward.

items.title: Bus driver admits mixing narcotics and booze on charter trip with Saskatoon school kids
items.summary_auto: A former Prince Albert bus driver admits he drove a charter with 52 Saskatoon grade school students while high on fentanyl, hydromorphone and hard liquor.

items.title: Iran boycotting World Cup draw citing visa restrictions for soccer officials
items.summary_auto: Iran has decided to boycott the 2026 World Cup draw in Washington next week because the U.S. denied visas to members of its delegation, the state-run IRNA news agency reported on Friday.

items.title: There will be no government money for Amelia Earhart restoration, says minister
items.summary_auto: Newfoundland and Labrador's new minister of Women and Gender Equality says there is no longer a need for government money to replace or restore the stolen Amelia Earhart statue, and is describing a media campaign by a Liberal MHA as "disingenuous."

items.title: Sask. child-care deal extended for 5 more years, expands eligibility for kids turning 6
items.summary_auto: The federal and Saskatchewan governments have reached a deal to extend the province’s $10-a-day child-care agreement for another five years, beginning in the 2026-27 fiscal year.

items.title: Ukraine presidential adviser Yermak resigns in another blow for Zelenskyy's government
items.summary_auto: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said on Friday that his chief of staff, Andriy Yermak, has submitted his resignation amid a corruption scandal. The departure comes at a perilous time for Kyiv as it faces U.S. pressure to make concessions to Moscow to end its war on Ukraine and lacks the soldiers or weapons to push Russian forces back.

items.title: Buy Canadian movement appears to be losing steam. Can holiday sales revive it?
UN calls for independent investigation into 'apparent summary execution' of 2 Palestinians in West Bank
items.summary_auto: Human rights groups are condemning the killing of two Palestinian men in the occupied West Bank by Israeli security forces, saying video capturing the incident showed the men appearing to surrender while unarmed before being shot dead.

items.title: Canada's economy sees surprise boost in 3rd quarter, avoiding a technical recession
items.summary_auto: The Canadian economy grew at an annualized rate of 2.6 per cent in the third quarter, Statistics Canada said on Friday, avoiding a technical recession largely due to a surge in defence spending.

items.title: Trump vows to clamp down on migration from developing nations after D.C. attack
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump has vowed to "permanently pause migration" from several countries, with his Department of Homeland Security prepared to carry out his policies.

items.title: Flood deaths in Southeast Asia reach 321 as rescuers step up recovery operations
items.summary_auto: The death toll from floods across large swaths of Southeast Asia rose to at least 321 on Friday, with authorities working to rescue stranded citizens, restore power and communications and co-ordinate recovery efforts as the waters began to recede.

items.title: If you want to shop ethically this holiday season just buy less, Guelph prof says
items.summary_auto: While it’s not always easy to shop with workers rights, animal welfare and the environment in mind, a University of Guelph professor says many customers want to support products made in Canada, with fair labour, or using environmentally-friendly practices.

items.title: ‘Cash for keys’ offers are making people homeless, say housing advocates in northern Ontario
items.summary_auto: Housing advocates in the northern Ontario city of Sudbury say “cash for keys” agreements are making people homeless over the long term.

items.title: Jamaican farm workers in N.S. prepare to head home to hurricane devastation
items.summary_auto: Jamaican farm workers in Nova Scotia are bracing for a difficult time when they return to their home country still reeling from the devastating impact of Hurricane Melissa.

items.title: My outlook on aging changed when my friend died. Here’s the clarity I found as I enter my 60s
items.summary_auto: Dana Kobernick never saw aging as a privilege. Then her longtime friend died, and her perception changed. As she enters her 60s, she’s learning to face life’s next steps with courage and gratitude, inspired by her friend’s resilience.

items.title: Government demanding public servants reimburse years-old Phoenix overpayments
items.summary_auto: Federal public servants are being threatened with legal action if they don’t repay money they were mistakenly overpaid during the error-plagued rollout of the Phoenix pay system nearly a decade ago, Radio-Canada has learned.

items.title: Some commercial lobster fishers say Indigenous treaty fishing threatens stocks. Government memo says otherwise
items.summary_auto: The fifth estate investigates misconceptions and allegations fuelling conflict in Canada’s largest lobster fishery, where Mi’kmaw fishers face broad opposition when exercising treaty rights.

items.title: The Carney-Smith agreement surely won't make pipelines 'boring again'
items.summary_auto: Guilbeault's resignation — the rare cabinet resignation due to a disagreement over government policy — both adds to and underlines the test of national and political leadership that Mark Carney signed up for when he put his signature on that memorandum.

items.title: Can Canadians still trust Canada Post with holiday mail after months of strikes?
items.summary_auto: Technically, the rotating Canada Post strikes are over. But can Canadians trust the corporation to get their Christmas cards and packages delivered on time? Here's what to know.

items.title: Why the White House blames National Guard shooting on program that brought Afghan nationals to the U.S.
items.summary_auto: The Trump White House is blaming Operation Allies Welcome, a Biden-era program that brought thousands of Afghan nationals to the U.S., for bringing the suspect in Wednesday's National Guard shooting to the U.S. Here's what we know about the program.

items.title: 'Tis the season for holiday shopping. But are Canadian products on the list?
items.summary_auto: Despite recent data suggesting the Buy Canadian movement is losing steam, some business owners are hopeful the boom they've been seeing will continue through Black Friday sales and throughout the holiday shopping season.
